Overlay-based Decentralized Federated Learning in Bandwidth-limited Networks

Yudi Huang Pennsylvania State UniversityState College, PAUSA yxh5389@psu.edu ,  Tingyang Sun Pennsylvania State UniversityState College, PAUSA tfs5679@psu.edu  and  Ting He Pennsylvania State UniversityState College, PAUSA tinghe@psu.edu
(2024)
Abstract.

The emerging machine learning paradigm of decentralized federated learning (DFL) has the promise of greatly boosting the deployment of artificial intelligence (AI) by directly learning across distributed agents without centralized coordination. Despite significant efforts on improving the communication efficiency of DFL, most existing solutions were based on the simplistic assumption that neighboring agents are physically adjacent in the underlying communication network, which fails to correctly capture the communication cost when learning over a general bandwidth-limited network, as encountered in many edge networks. In this work, we address this gap by leveraging recent advances in network tomography to jointly design the communication demands and the communication schedule for overlay-based DFL in bandwidth-limited networks without requiring explicit cooperation from the underlying network. By carefully analyzing the structure of our problem, we decompose it into a series of optimization problems that can each be solved efficiently, to collectively minimize the total training time. Extensive data-driven simulations show that our solution can significantly accelerate DFL in comparison with state-of-the-art designs.

Decentralized federated learning, network tomography, overlay routing, mixing matrix design.

1. Introduction

As a new machine learning paradigm, federated learning (FL) allows multiple learning agents to collaboratively learn a shared model from the union of their local data without directly sharing the data (McMahan et al., 2017). To achieve this goal, the agents repeatedly exchange model updates, through a centralized parameter server (McMahan et al., 2017), a hierarchy of parameter servers (Liu et al., 2023), or peer-to-peer links between neighboring agents (Kairouz et al., 2021), which are then aggregated to update the shared model. Due to its promise in protecting data privacy, FL has found many applications such as improving browsers (FLo, [n. d.]; Bra, [n. d.]). In particular, decentralized federated learning (DFL) (Lian et al., 2017) has attracted significant attention. Instead of forming a star (McMahan et al., 2017) or hierarchical topology (Liu et al., 2023), agents in DFL can communicate along arbitrary topology, where parameter exchanges only occur between neighbors. Compared to centralized FL, DFL can avoid a single point of failure and reduce the communication complexity at the busiest node without increasing the computational complexity (Lian et al., 2017).

Meanwhile, FL including DFL faces significant performance challenges due to the extensive data transfer. Although the training data stay local, the agents still need to communicate frequently to exchange local model updates, which often incurs a nontrivial communication cost due to the large model size. Such communication cost can dominate the total cost of the learning task, e.g., accounting for up to 90%percent9090\% of time in cloud-based FL (Luo et al., 2020), and the problem is exacerbated in other networks that are more bandwidth-limited (e.g., wireless mesh networks (Chen et al., 2022b)). This issue has attracted tremendous interests in reducing the communication cost, including compression-based methods for reducing the amount of data per communication such as (Koloskova et al., 2020a) and methods for reducing the number of communications through hyperparameter optimization such as (Wang et al., 2019, 2022b; Chiu et al., 2023) or adaptive communications such as (Singh et al., 2022).

However, most existing works made the simplistic assumption that each pair of logically adjacent agents are also physically adjacent in the underlying communication network. This is not true in overlay-based DFL, where the connections between logically adjacent agents (i.e., overlay links) can map to arbitrary routing paths in the underlying communication network that may share links (i.e., underlay links). For example, a set of learning agents {A,B,C,D}𝐴𝐵𝐶𝐷\{A,B,C,D\} may have the physical connectivity in Fig. 1a and the logical connectivity in Fig. 1b. Although connections (A,B)𝐴𝐵(A,B) and (C,D)𝐶𝐷(C,D) appear disjoint in the overlay, they actually map to paths sharing link (h1,h2)subscriptℎ1subscriptℎ2(h_{1},h_{2}) in the underlay. Ignoring such link sharing can cause incorrect prediction of the communication time, because concurrent communications over connections with shared links can take longer than stand-alone communication on each of them, and the problem can be exacerbated by heterogeneous capacities and background loads at underlay links. Most existing works ignored such complications by assuming the communication time to be proportional to the maximum number of neighbors an agent communicates with (Wang et al., 2022b; Chiu et al., 2023; Hua et al., 2022; Le Bars et al., 2023), which generally leads to suboptimal designs in the case of overlay-based DFL.

We want to address this gap without requiring explicit cooperation from the underlay network, i.e., the agents can neither directly observe the internal state of the underlay (e.g., routing topology, link capacities) nor control its internal behavior. Such scenarios arise naturally when the agents are interconnected by a public network. In particular, we are interested in running DFL over bandwidth-limited networks, which models many application scenarios such as HetNets (Chen et al., 2022b), device-to-device networks (Xing et al., 2021), IoT networks (Pinyoanuntapong et al., 2022), underwater networks (Pei et al., 2023), and power line communication networks (Jia et al., 2022). In contrast to high-bandwidth networks such as inter-datacenter networks (Marfoq et al., 2020), bandwidth-limited networks are more sensitive to communication demands generated by DFL and are thus in greater needs of proper designs. To this end, we propose an optimization framework for overlay-based DFL that jointly designs the communication demands and the communication schedule within the overlay, without explicit cooperation from the underlay. Building upon recent advances in network tomography (Huang and He, 2023) and mixing matrix design (Chiu et al., 2023), we cast the problem into a set of tractable optimizations that collectively minimize the total time in achieving a given level of convergence.

1.1. Related Work

Decentralized federated learning. Initially proposed under a centralized architecture (McMahan et al., 2017), FL was later extended to a fully decentralized architecture (Lian et al., 2017), which was shown to achieve the same computational complexity but a lower communication complexity. Since then a number of improvements have been developed, e.g., (Tang et al., 2018b; Lu and Sa, 2021), but these works only focused on reducing the number of iterations.

Communication cost reduction. There are two general approaches for reducing the communication cost in FL: reducing the amount of data per communication through compression, e.g., (Koloskova et al., 2020a; Lu and De Sa, 2020; Tang et al., 2018a), and reducing the number of communications, e.g., (Wang and Joshi, 2019; Tran et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019). The two approaches can be combined for further improvement (Singh et al., 2022, 2021). Instead of either activating all the links or activating none, it has been recognized that better efficiency can be achieved by activating subsets of links. To this end, (Singh et al., 2022, 2021) proposed an event-triggered mechanism and (Wang et al., 2022b; Chiu et al., 2023) proposed to activate links with predetermined probabilities. In this regard, our work designs predetermined link activation as in (Wang et al., 2022b; Chiu et al., 2023), which provides more predictable performance than event-triggered mechanisms, but we consider a cost model tailored to overlay-based DFL: instead of measuring the communication time by the number of matchings (Wang et al., 2022b; Chiu et al., 2023) or the maximum degree (Hua et al., 2022; Le Bars et al., 2023), we evaluate the minimum time to complete all the activated agent-to-agent communications over a bandwidth-limited underlay, while taking into account heterogeneous capacities and possibly shared links.

Topology design in DFL. The logical topology defining the neighborhoods of learning agents is an important design parameter in DFL that controls the communication demands during training. The impact of this topology on the convergence rate of DFL has been mostly captured through the spectral gap of the mixing matrix (Lian et al., 2017; Nedić et al., 2018; Neglia et al., 2019, 2020; Jiang et al., 2023) or equivalent parameters (Wang et al., 2022b). Although recent works have identified other parameters that can impact the convergence rate, such as the effective number of neighbors (Vogels et al., 2022) and the neighborhood heterogeneity (Le Bars et al., 2023), these results just pointed out additional factors and did not invalidate the impact of spectral gap. Based on the identified convergence parameters, several solutions have been proposed to design the logical topology to balance the convergence rate and the cost per communication round (Wang et al., 2022b; Chiu et al., 2023; Le Bars et al., 2023), and some solutions combined topology design with other optimizations (e.g., bandwidth allocation (Wang et al., 2022a), model pruning (Jiang et al., 2023)) for further improvement. In this regard, our work also includes topology design based on a parameter related to the spectral gap, but we explicitly consider the communication schedule to serve the demands triggered by the designed topology over a bandwidth-limited underlay to optimize the overall wall-clock time of overlay-based DFL. To our knowledge, the only existing work addressing overlay-based DFL is (Marfoq et al., 2020). However, it assumed a special underlay where the paths connecting learning agents only share links at the first and the last hops, whose capacities are assumed to be known. While this model may suit high-bandwidth underlays such as inter-datacenter networks, it fails to capture the communication cost in bandwidth-limited underlays as addressed in our work.

Network-aware distributed computing. It was known that awareness to the state of the communication underlay is important for data-intensive distributed computing tasks (Luo et al., 2020). Several works attempted to solve this problem in the context of cloud networks, assuming either a black-box network (Luo et al., 2020; Gong et al., 2015; LaCurts et al., 2013) or a white-box network (Chen et al., 2022a). In this regard, our work assumes a black-box underlay as in (Luo et al., 2020; Gong et al., 2015; LaCurts et al., 2013), but unlike the simple heuristics used in these works, we leverage state-of-the-art techniques from network tomography (He et al., 2021) to estimate the necessary parameters about the underlay. Notably, we recently discovered in (Huang and He, 2023) that network tomography can consistently estimate coarse parameters about the underlay that allows the overlay to compute the capacity region for communications between the overlay nodes, which we will use to design the communication schedule for overlay-based DFL.

1.2. Summary of Contributions

We jointly design the communication demands and the communication schedule for overlay-based DFL in a bandwidth-limited uncooperative underlay, with the following contributions:

  1. (1)

    We consider, for the first time, communication optimization in DFL on top of a bandwidth-limited underlay network with arbitrary topology. To this end, we propose a general framework for jointly designing the communication demands and the communication schedule (e.g., routing, rates) among the learning agents, without cooperation from the underlay.

  2. (2)

    We tackle the complexity challenge by decomposing the overall problem into a series of smaller subproblems, that are collectively designed to minimize the total training time to achieve a given level of convergence. Through carefully designed relaxations, we convert each subproblem into a tractable optimization to develop efficient solutions.

  3. (3)

    We evaluate the proposed solution in comparison with benchmarks based on real network topologies and datasets. Our results show that (i) our design of the communication demands can already reduce the training time substantially without compromising the quality of the trained model, (ii) our design of the communication schedule further increases the improvement, and (iii) the observations remain valid under realistic inference errors about the underlay.

Roadmap. Section 2 describes our overall problem, Section 3 presents our solution and analysis, Section 4 presents our performance evaluation, and Section 5 concludes the paper. All the proofs can be found in Appendix A.

2.2. Network Model

Consider a network of m𝑚m learning agents connected through a logical base topology G=(V,E)𝐺𝑉𝐸G=(V,E) (|V|=m𝑉𝑚|V|=m), that forms an overlay on top of a communication underlay G¯=(V¯,E¯)¯𝐺¯𝑉¯𝐸\underline{G}=(\underline{V},\underline{E}). Unless otherwise stated, both overlay and underlay links are considered directed. Each underlay link e¯∈E¯¯𝑒¯𝐸\underline{e}\in\underline{E} has a finite capacity Ce¯subscript𝐶¯𝑒C_{\underline{e}}. Each overlay link e=(i,j)∈E𝑒𝑖𝑗𝐸e=(i,j)\in E indicates that agent i𝑖i is allowed to communicate to agent j𝑗j during learning, and is implemented via a routing path p¯i,jsubscript¯𝑝𝑖𝑗\underline{p}_{i,j} from the node running agent i𝑖i to the node running agent j𝑗j in the underlay. We assume that if (i,j)∈E𝑖𝑗𝐸(i,j)\in E, then (j,i)∈E𝑗𝑖𝐸(j,i)\in E (agents i𝑖i and j𝑗j are allowed to exchange results). The routing paths are determined by the topology and the routing protocol in the underlay. Let li,jsubscript𝑙𝑖𝑗l_{i,j} denote the propagation delay on p¯i,jsubscript¯𝑝𝑖𝑗\underline{p}_{i,j}. We assume that neither the routing paths nor the link capacities in the underlay are observable by the overlay, but the propagation delays between overlay nodes (e.g., li,jsubscript𝑙𝑖𝑗l_{i,j}) are observable111This can be obtained by measuring the delays of small probing packets..

2.3. Decentralized Federated Learning (DFL)

(1) F​(𝒙):=1m​∑i=1mFi​(𝒙).assign𝐹𝒙1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝐹𝑖𝒙\displaystyle F(\bm{x}):=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^{m}F_{i}(\bm{x}).

For example, we can model the objective of empirical risk minimization by defining the local objective as Fi​(𝒙):=∑𝒔∈𝒟iℓ​(𝒙,𝒔)assignsubscript𝐹𝑖𝒙subscript𝒔subscript𝒟𝑖ℓ𝒙𝒔F_{i}(\bm{x}):=\sum_{\bm{s}\in\mathcal{D}_{i}}\ell(\bm{x},\bm{s}), where ℓ​(𝒙,𝒔)ℓ𝒙𝒔\ell(\bm{x},\bm{s}) is the loss function for sample 𝒔𝒔\bm{s} under model 𝒙𝒙\bm{x}, and the corresponding global objective is proportional to the empirical risk over all the samples.

We consider a standard decentralized training algorithm called D-PSGD (Lian et al., 2017), where each agent repeatedly updates its own parameter vector and aggregates it with the parameter vectors of its neighbors to minimize the global objective function. 2.4. Design Objective

Our goal is to jointly design the communication demands between the agents and the communication schedule about how to service these demands so as to minimize the total (wall-clock) time for the learning task to reach a given level of convergence. The challenges are two-fold: (i) the design of communication demands faces the tradeoff between communicating more per iteration and converging in fewer iterations versus communicating less per iteration and converging in more iterations, and (ii) the design of communication schedule faces the lack of observability and controllability within the underlay network. Below, we will tackle these challenges by combining techniques from network tomography and mixing matrix design.

3. Proposed Solution

Our approach is to first characterize the total training time as an explicit function of the set of activated links in the overlay, and then optimize this set. We will focus on a deterministic design that can give a predictable training time, and thus the iteration index k𝑘k will be omitted. For ease of presentation, we will consider the set of activated overlay links, denoted by Ea⊆E~subscript𝐸𝑎~𝐸E_{a}\subseteq\widetilde{E}, as undirected links, as the pair of links between two agents must be activated at the same time.

3.1. Communication Schedule Optimization

Given a set of overlay links Ea⊆E~subscript𝐸𝑎~𝐸E_{a}\subseteq\widetilde{E} activated in an iteration, each (i,j)∈Ea𝑖𝑗subscript𝐸𝑎(i,j)\in E_{a} triggers two communications, one for agent i𝑖i to send its parameter vector to agent j𝑗j and the other for agent j𝑗j to send its parameter vector to agent i𝑖i. However, directly sending the parameter vectors along the underlay routing paths can lead to suboptimal performance. For example, consider Fig. 2. If Ea={(A,B),(A,D)}subscript𝐸𝑎𝐴𝐵𝐴𝐷E_{a}=\{(A,B),(A,D)\} but both p¯A,Bsubscript¯𝑝𝐴𝐵\underline{p}_{A,B} and p¯A,Dsubscript¯𝑝𝐴𝐷\underline{p}_{A,D} traverse the same underlay link (h1,h2)subscriptℎ1subscriptℎ2(h_{1},h_{2}), directly communicating between the activated agent pairs can take longer than redirecting part of the traffic through other agents (e.g., redirecting A→D→𝐴𝐷A\to D traffic through the overlay path A→C→D→𝐴𝐶→𝐷A\to C\to D). The same holds if the capacity of the direct path is low, but the capacity through other agents is higher (e.g., if (h2,D)subscriptℎ2𝐷(h_{2},D) is a slow link, then redirecting A→D→𝐴𝐷A\to D traffic through C𝐶C can bypass it to achieve a higher rate). This observation motivates the need of optimizing how to serve the demands triggered by the activated links by routing within the overlay.

3.1.1. Demand Model

Let κisubscript𝜅𝑖\kappa_{i} denote the size of the parameter vector (or its compressed version if model compression is used) at agent i𝑖i. A straightforward way to model the communication demands triggered by a set of activated links Easubscript𝐸𝑎E_{a} is to generate two unicast flows for each activated link (i,j)∈Ea𝑖𝑗subscript𝐸𝑎(i,j)\in E_{a}, one in each direction. However, this model will lead to a suboptimal communication schedule as it ignores the fact that some flows carry identical content. Specifically, all flows originating from the same agent will carry the latest parameter vector at this agent. Thus, the actual communication demands is a set of multicast flows, each for distributing the parameter vector of an activated agent (incident to at least one activated link) to the agents it needs to share parameters with. Let NEa​(i):={j∈V:(i,j)∈Ea}assignsubscript𝑁subscript𝐸𝑎𝑖conditional-set𝑗𝑉𝑖𝑗subscript𝐸𝑎N_{E_{a}}(i):=\{j\in V:\>(i,j)\in E_{a}\}. We can express the demands triggered by the activated links Easubscript𝐸𝑎E_{a} as

(4) H={(i,NEa​(i),κi):∀i∈V​ with ​NEa​(i)≠∅},𝐻conditional-set𝑖subscript𝑁subscript𝐸𝑎𝑖subscript𝜅𝑖for-all𝑖𝑉 with subscript𝑁subscript𝐸𝑎𝑖\displaystyle H=\{(i,N_{E_{a}}(i),\kappa_{i}):\>\forall i\in V\mbox{ with }N_{E_{a}}(i)\neq\emptyset\},

where each h=(sh,Th,κh)∈Hℎsubscript𝑠ℎsubscript𝑇ℎsubscript𝜅ℎ𝐻h=(s_{h},T_{h},\kappa_{h})\in H represents a multicast flow with source shsubscript𝑠ℎs_{h}, destinations Thsubscript𝑇ℎT_{h}, and data size κhsubscript𝜅ℎ\kappa_{h}.

3.1.2. Baseline Formulation

To help towards minimizing the total training time, the communication schedule should minimize the time for completing all the communication demands triggered by the activated links, within the control of the overlay. To this end, we jointly optimize the routing and the flow rate within the overlay. Constraint (5b) makes τ𝜏\tau an upper bound on the completion time of the slowest flow; (5c) ensures that the total traffic rate imposed by the overlay on any underlay link is within its capacity; (5d)–(5e) are the Steiner arborescence constraints (Goemans and Myung, 1993) that guarantee the set of overlay links with zi​jh=1subscriptsuperscript𝑧ℎ𝑖𝑗1z^{h}_{ij}=1 will form a Steiner arborescence (i.e., a directed Steiner tree) that is the union of paths from shsubscript𝑠ℎs_{h} to each k∈Th𝑘subscript𝑇ℎk\in T_{h} (where each path is formed by the links with ri​jh,k=1subscriptsuperscript𝑟ℎ𝑘𝑖𝑗1r^{h,k}_{ij}=1); (5f) implies that fi​jh=dhsubscriptsuperscript𝑓ℎ𝑖𝑗subscript𝑑ℎf^{h}_{ij}=d_{h} if zi​jh=1subscriptsuperscript𝑧ℎ𝑖𝑗1z^{h}_{ij}=1 and (5g) together with (5h) implies that fi​jh=0subscriptsuperscript𝑓ℎ𝑖𝑗0f^{h}_{ij}=0 if zi​jh=0subscriptsuperscript𝑧ℎ𝑖𝑗0z^{h}_{ij}=0, which allows the capacity constraint to be formulated as a linear inequality (5c) instead of a bilinear inequality ∑(i,j)∈E:e¯∈p¯i,j∑h∈Hdh​zi​jh≤Ce¯subscript:𝑖𝑗𝐸¯𝑒subscript¯𝑝𝑖𝑗subscriptℎ𝐻subscript𝑑ℎsubscriptsuperscript𝑧ℎ𝑖𝑗subscript𝐶¯𝑒\sum_{(i,j)\in E:\underline{e}\in\underline{p}_{i,j}}\sum_{h\in H}d_{h}z^{h}_{ij}\leq C_{\underline{e}}. The optimal solution (𝒛∗,𝒓∗,𝒅∗,𝒇∗)superscript𝒛superscript𝒓superscript𝒅superscript𝒇(\bm{z}^{*},\bm{r}^{*},\bm{d}^{*},\bm{f}^{*}) to (5) provides an overlay communication schedule that minimizes the communication time in a given iteration when the set of activated links is Easubscript𝐸𝑎E_{a}.

Complexity: As |H|≤|V|𝐻𝑉|H|\leq|V|, the optimization (5) contains O​(|V|2​|E|)𝑂superscript𝑉2𝐸O(|V|^{2}|E|) variables (dominated by 𝒓𝒓\bm{r}), and O​(|E¯|+|V|2​(|V|+|E|))𝑂¯𝐸superscript𝑉2𝑉𝐸O(|\underline{E}|+|V|^{2}(|V|+|E|)) constraints. Since constraints (5c)–(5f) are linear and constraint (5b) is convex, the optimization (5) is a mixed integer convex programming (MICP) problem and thus can be solved by existing MICP solvers such as Pajarito (Lubin, 2017) at a super-polynomial complexity or approximate MICP algorithms such as convex relaxation plus randomized rounding at a polynomial complexity.

3.1.3. Important Special Case

In the practical application scenario where the underlay is an edge network spanning a relatively small area, the propagation delay li,jsubscript𝑙𝑖𝑗l_{i,j} will be negligible compared to the data transfer time. Moreover, since all the agents are training the same model, the sizes of the local parameter vectors will be identical without compression, i.e., κi≡κsubscript𝜅𝑖𝜅\kappa_{i}\equiv\kappa (∀i∈Vfor-all𝑖𝑉\forall i\in V). Even if compression is used, since the compressed model sizes will vary dynamically across iterations, tailoring the communication schedule to the compressed model sizes will require re-solving (5) for every iteration, which is expensive in terms of both the overhead in collecting all the compressed model sizes and the computation cost. It is thus more practical to optimize the communication schedule only once at the beginning of the learning task and use it throughout the task, and setting κi≡κsubscript𝜅𝑖𝜅\kappa_{i}\equiv\kappa (the uncompressed model size) in solving (5) will provide a guaranteed per-iteration time, even though compression can be applied during training to further reduce the time. In this scenario, the completion time for a given multicast flow h∈Hℎ𝐻h\in H is reduced to κ/dh𝜅subscript𝑑ℎ\kappa/d_{h}, and the overall completion time of an iteration is reduced to κ/(minh∈H⁡dh)𝜅subscriptℎ𝐻subscript𝑑ℎ\kappa/(\min_{h\in H}d_{h}). For this simplified objective, we observe the following property.

Lemma 3.1.

Given a feasible routing solution 𝒛𝒛\bm{z} to (5), define

(6) te¯:=|{h∈H,(i,j)∈E:zi​jh=1,e¯∈p¯i​j}|assignsubscript𝑡¯𝑒conditional-setformulae-sequenceℎ𝐻𝑖𝑗𝐸formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript𝑧ℎ𝑖𝑗1¯𝑒subscript¯𝑝𝑖𝑗\displaystyle t_{\underline{e}}:=|\{h\in H,(i,j)\in E:\>z^{h}_{ij}=1,\underline{e}\in\underline{p}_{ij}\}|

as the number of activated unicast flows444Although the logical demands is a set of multicast flows as in (4), the multicast operations can only be performed at overlay nodes, according to logical multicast trees formed by overlay links. Each hop in such a tree, corresponding to some zi​jh=1subscriptsuperscript𝑧ℎ𝑖𝑗1z^{h}_{ij}=1, is implemented by a unicast flow through the underlay, hereafter referred to as an “activated unicast flow”. traversing each underlay link e¯∈E¯¯𝑒¯𝐸\underline{e}\in\underline{E}. If li,j=0subscript𝑙𝑖𝑗0l_{i,j}=0 ∀(i,j)∈Efor-all𝑖𝑗𝐸\forall(i,j)\in E and κh≡κsubscript𝜅ℎ𝜅\kappa_{h}\equiv\kappa ∀h∈Hfor-allℎ𝐻\forall h\in H, then the optimal value of (5) under the given routing solution 𝒛𝒛\bm{z} is

Remark: Lemma 3.1 implies that for li,j=0subscript𝑙𝑖𝑗0l_{i,j}=0 ∀(i,j)∈Efor-all𝑖𝑗𝐸\forall(i,j)\in E and κh≡κsubscript𝜅ℎ𝜅\kappa_{h}\equiv\kappa ∀h∈Hfor-allℎ𝐻\forall h\in H, solving (5) is reduced to optimizing the routing 𝒛𝒛\bm{z} among the overlay nodes, after which the flow rates can be easily determined as dh≡mine¯∈E¯⁡Ce¯/te¯subscript𝑑ℎsubscript¯𝑒¯𝐸subscript𝐶¯𝑒subscript𝑡¯𝑒d_{h}\equiv\min_{\underline{e}\in\underline{E}}C_{\underline{e}}/t_{\underline{e}} ∀h∈Hfor-allℎ𝐻\forall h\in H (note that 𝒓,𝒇𝒓𝒇\bm{r},\bm{f} are dependent variables determined by 𝒛,𝒅𝒛𝒅\bm{z},\bm{d}). More importantly, Lemma 3.1 implies that if each activated unicast flow is implemented as a TCP flow (using the same congestion control algorithm), then the minimum completion time will be automatically achieved in the steady state as long as the routing is optimal.

3.1.4. Handling Uncooperative Underlay

When learning over an uncooperative underlay as considered in this work, the overlay cannot directly solve (5), because the capacity constraint (5c) requires the knowledge of the routing in the underlay and the capacities of the underlay links. In absence of such knowledge, we leverage a recent result from (Huang and He, 2023) to convert this constraint into an equivalent form that can be consistently estimated by the overlay. To this end, we introduce the following notion from (Huang and He, 2023), adapted to our problem setting.

Definition 0 ((Huang and He, 2023)).

A category of underlay links ΓFsubscriptΓ𝐹\Gamma_{F} for a set of overlay links F𝐹F (F⊆E𝐹𝐸F\subseteq E) is the set of underlay links traversed by and only by the underlay routing paths for the overlay links in F𝐹F out of all the paths for E𝐸E, i.e,555Here p¯¯𝑝\underline{p} is interpreted as the set of underlay links traversed by path p¯¯𝑝\underline{p}.

(8) ΓF≔(⋂(i,j)∈Fp¯i,j)∖(⋃(i,j)∈E∖Fp¯i,j).≔subscriptΓ𝐹subscript𝑖𝑗𝐹subscript¯𝑝𝑖𝑗subscript𝑖𝑗𝐸𝐹subscript¯𝑝𝑖𝑗\displaystyle\Gamma_{F}\coloneqq\Big{(}\bigcap_{(i,j)\in{F}}\underline{p}_{i,j}\Big{)}\setminus\Big{(}\bigcup_{(i,j)\in E\setminus F}\underline{p}_{i,j}\Big{)}.

The key observation is that since all the underlay links in the same category are traversed by the same set of overlay links, they must carry the same traffic load from the overlay. Therefore, we can reduce the per-link capacity constraint (5c) into the following per-category capacity constraint:

(9) ∑(i,j)∈F∑h∈Hfi​jh≤CF,∀F⊆E​ with ​ΓF≠∅,formulae-sequencesubscript𝑖𝑗𝐹subscriptℎ𝐻subscriptsuperscript𝑓ℎ𝑖𝑗subscript𝐶𝐹for-all𝐹𝐸 with subscriptΓ𝐹\displaystyle\sum_{(i,j)\in{F}}\sum_{h\in H}f^{h}_{ij}\leq C_{F},~{}~{}~{}\forall F\subseteq E\mbox{ with }\Gamma_{F}\neq\emptyset,

where CF≔mine¯∈ΓF⁡Ce¯≔subscript𝐶𝐹subscript¯𝑒subscriptΓ𝐹subscript𝐶¯𝑒C_{F}\coloneqq\min_{\underline{e}\in\Gamma_{F}}C_{\underline{e}}, referred to as the category capacity, is the minimum capacity of all the links in category ΓFsubscriptΓ𝐹\Gamma_{F}. The new constraint (9) is equivalent to the original constraint (5c), as an overlay communication schedule satisfies one of these constraints if and only if it satisfies the other. However, instead of requiring detailed internal information about the underlay (i.e., (p¯i,j)(i,j)∈Esubscriptsubscript¯𝑝𝑖𝑗𝑖𝑗𝐸(\underline{p}_{i,j})_{(i,j)\in E} and (Ce¯)e¯∈E¯subscriptsubscript𝐶¯𝑒¯𝑒¯𝐸(C_{\underline{e}})_{\underline{e}\in\underline{E}}), constraint (9) only requires the knowledge of the nonempty categories and the corresponding category capacities.

In the special case of li,j=0subscript𝑙𝑖𝑗0l_{i,j}=0 ∀(i,j)∈Efor-all𝑖𝑗𝐸\forall(i,j)\in E and κh≡κsubscript𝜅ℎ𝜅\kappa_{h}\equiv\kappa ∀h∈Hfor-allℎ𝐻\forall h\in H, we have a category-based counterpart of Lemma 3.1 as follows.

Lemma 3.3.

Given a feasible routing solution 𝒛𝒛\bm{z} to (5), define

(10) tF:=|{h∈H,(i,j)∈F:zi​jh=1}|assignsubscript𝑡𝐹conditional-setformulae-sequenceℎ𝐻𝑖𝑗𝐹subscriptsuperscript𝑧ℎ𝑖𝑗1\displaystyle t_{F}:=|\{h\in H,(i,j)\in F:\>z^{h}_{ij}=1\}|

as the number of activated unicast flows traversing the links in category ΓFsubscriptΓ𝐹\Gamma_{F}. If li,j=0subscript𝑙𝑖𝑗0l_{i,j}=0 ∀(i,j)∈Efor-all𝑖𝑗𝐸\forall(i,j)\in E and κh≡κsubscript𝜅ℎ𝜅\kappa_{h}\equiv\kappa ∀h∈Hfor-allℎ𝐻\forall h\in H, then the optimal value of (5) under the given routing solution 𝒛𝒛\bm{z} is

(11) τ=κminF∈ℱ⁡CF/tF,𝜏𝜅subscript𝐹ℱsubscript𝐶𝐹subscript𝑡𝐹\displaystyle\tau={\kappa\over\min_{F\in\mathcal{F}}C_{F}/t_{F}},

achieved by equally sharing the bandwidth at every underlay link among the activated unicast flows traversing it, where ℱ:={F⊆E:ΓF≠∅}assignℱconditional-set𝐹𝐸subscriptΓ𝐹\mathcal{F}:=\{F\subseteq E:\Gamma_{F}\neq\emptyset\}.

Under the assumption that every underlay link introduces a nontrivial performance impact (e.g., non-zero loss/queueing probability), (Huang and He, 2023) provided an algorithm that can consistently infer the nonempty categories from losses/delays of packets sent concurrently through the overlay links, under the assumption that concurrently sent packets will experience the same performance when traversing a shared underlay link. Moreover, by leveraging state-of-the-art single-path residual capacity estimation methods, (Huang and He, 2023) gave a simple algorithm that can accurately estimate the effective category capacity C~Fsubscript~𝐶𝐹\widetilde{C}_{F} for each detected nonempty category, that can be used in place of CFsubscript𝐶𝐹C_{F} in (9) without changing the feasible region. Given the indices of inferred nonempty categories ℱ^^ℱ\widehat{\mathcal{F}} and their inferred effective capacities (C^F)F∈ℱ^subscriptsubscript^𝐶𝐹𝐹^ℱ(\widehat{C}_{F})_{F\in\widehat{\mathcal{F}}}, we can construct the per-category capacity constraint as

(12) ∑(i,j)∈F∑h∈Hfi​jh≤C^F,∀F∈ℱ^,formulae-sequencesubscript𝑖𝑗𝐹subscriptℎ𝐻subscriptsuperscript𝑓ℎ𝑖𝑗subscript^𝐶𝐹for-all𝐹^ℱ\displaystyle\sum_{(i,j)\in{F}}\sum_{h\in H}f^{h}_{ij}\leq\widehat{C}_{F},~{}~{}~{}\forall F\in\widehat{\mathcal{F}},

which can then be used in place of (5c) in (5) to compute an optimized overlay communication schedule. In the special case considered in Lemma 3.3, we can estimate the minimum completion time under a given routing solution by

(13) τ^:=κminF∈ℱ^⁡C^F/tF.assign^𝜏𝜅subscript𝐹^ℱsubscript^𝐶𝐹subscript𝑡𝐹\displaystyle\widehat{\tau}:={\kappa\over\min_{F\in\widehat{\mathcal{F}}}\widehat{C}_{F}/t_{F}}.

Remark: First, the traversal of overlay paths through the overlay links is directional, and the traversal of underlay routing paths through the underlay links is also directional. Correspondingly, the overlay links in a category index F𝐹F should be treated as directed links (i.e., (i,j)∈F𝑖𝑗𝐹(i,j)\in F only implies that the underlay links in ΓFsubscriptΓ𝐹\Gamma_{F} are traversed by the path p¯i,jsubscript¯𝑝𝑖𝑗\underline{p}_{i,j}). This is not to be confused with treating the activated links in Easubscript𝐸𝑎E_{a} as undirected links, because each (i,j)∈Ea𝑖𝑗subscript𝐸𝑎(i,j)\in E_{a} stands for a parameter exchange between agents i𝑖i and j𝑗j. Moreover, we only use the activated links Easubscript𝐸𝑎E_{a} to determine the flow demands H𝐻H, but any overlay link in E𝐸E can be used in serving these flows.

3.1.5. Additional Optimization Opportunities and Challenges

The formulation (5) treats each overlay node that is neither the source nor one of the destinations of a multicast flow as a pure relay, but this node is actually a learning agent capable of aggregating the parameter vectors. This observation raises two questions: (i) Can an agent include parameter vectors relayed through it in its own parameter aggregation? (ii) If an agent relays multiple parameter vectors for different sources, can it forward the aggregated vector instead of the individual vectors?

To answer the first question, consider the case in Fig. 2 when A𝐴A sends its parameter vector 𝒙Asubscript𝒙𝐴\bm{x}_{A} to D𝐷D through the overlay path A→C→D→𝐴𝐶→𝐷A\to C\to D. If C𝐶C includes 𝒙Asubscript𝒙𝐴\bm{x}_{A} in its own parameter aggregation with a non-zero weight WC​Asubscript𝑊𝐶𝐴W_{CA}, then by the symmetry of the mixing matrix, A𝐴A must also include 𝒙Csubscript𝒙𝐶\bm{x}_{C} in its parameter aggregation with weight WA​C=WC​Asubscript𝑊𝐴𝐶subscript𝑊𝐶𝐴W_{AC}=W_{CA}, which is equivalent to activating the overlay link (A,C)𝐴𝐶(A,C). As we have left the optimization of the activated links Easubscript𝐸𝑎E_{a} to another subproblem (Section 3.3), there is no need to include relayed parameter vectors in parameter aggregation when optimizing the communication schedule for a given set of activated links.

To answer the second question, consider the case in Fig. 3 when the overlay routes the multicast from A𝐴A to {D,E}𝐷𝐸\{D,E\} (for disseminating 𝒙Asubscript𝒙𝐴\bm{x}_{A}) over A→C→D→E→𝐴𝐶→𝐷→𝐸A\to C\to D\to E, and the multicast from B𝐵B to {D,E}𝐷𝐸\{D,E\} (for disseminating 𝒙Bsubscript𝒙𝐵\bm{x}_{B}) over B→C→D→E→𝐵𝐶→𝐷→𝐸B\to C\to D\to E. Although instead of separately forwarding 𝒙Asubscript𝒙𝐴\bm{x}_{A} and 𝒙Bsubscript𝒙𝐵\bm{x}_{B}, C𝐶C could aggregate them before forwarding, the aggregation will not save bandwidth for C𝐶C, as D𝐷D needs WD​A​𝒙A+WD​B​𝒙Bsubscript𝑊𝐷𝐴subscript𝒙𝐴subscript𝑊𝐷𝐵subscript𝒙𝐵W_{DA}\bm{x}_{A}+W_{DB}\bm{x}_{B} but E𝐸E needs WE​A​𝒙A+WE​B​𝒙Bsubscript𝑊𝐸𝐴subscript𝒙𝐴subscript𝑊𝐸𝐵subscript𝒙𝐵W_{EA}\bm{x}_{A}+W_{EB}\bm{x}_{B}, which are generally not the same. Another issue with in-network aggregation (within the overlay) is the synchronization delay introduced at the point of aggregation, and thus in-network aggregation may not reduce the completion time even when it can save bandwidth, e.g., at D𝐷D. We thus choose not to consider in-network aggregation in our formulation (5). Further optimizations exploiting such capabilities are left to future work.

3.2. Link Weight Optimization

Given the set of activated links Ea⊆E~subscript𝐸𝑎~𝐸E_{a}\subseteq\widetilde{E}, the communication time per iteration has been determined as explained in Section 3.1, but the number of iterations has not, and is heavily affected by the weights of the activated links. This leads to the question of how to minimize the number of iterations for achieving a desired level of convergence, under the constraint that only the activated links can have non-zero weights.

To answer this question, we leverage a state-of-the-art convergence bound for D-PSGD under the following assumptions:

  1. (1)

    Each local objective function Fi​(𝒙)subscript𝐹𝑖𝒙F_{i}(\bm{x}) is l𝑙l-Lipschitz smooth, i.e., ‖∇Fi​(𝒙)−∇Fi​(𝒙′)‖≤l​‖𝒙−𝒙′‖,∀i∈Vformulae-sequencenorm∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝒙∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscript𝒙′𝑙norm𝒙superscript𝒙′for-all𝑖𝑉\|\nabla F_{i}(\bm{x})-\nabla F_{i}(\bm{x}^{\prime})\|\leq l\|\bm{x}-\bm{x}^{\prime}\|,\>\forall i\in V.

  2. (2)

    There exist constants M1,σ^subscript𝑀1^𝜎M_{1},\widehat{\sigma} such that 1m​∑i∈VIE​[‖g​(𝒙i;ξi)−∇Fi​(𝒙i)‖2]≤σ^2+M1m​∑i∈V‖∇F​(𝒙i)‖21𝑚subscript𝑖𝑉IEdelimited-[]superscriptnorm𝑔subscript𝒙𝑖subscript𝜉𝑖∇subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝒙𝑖2superscript^𝜎2subscript𝑀1𝑚subscript𝑖𝑉superscriptnorm∇𝐹subscript𝒙𝑖2{1\over m}\sum_{i\in V}{\rm I\kern-3.00003ptE}[\|g(\bm{x}_{i};\xi_{i})-\nabla F_{i}(\bm{x}_{i})\|^{2}]\leq\widehat{\sigma}^{2}+{M_{1}\over m}\sum_{i\in V}\|\nabla F(\bm{x}_{i})\|^{2}, ∀𝒙1,…,𝒙m∈ℝdfor-allsubscript𝒙1…subscript𝒙𝑚superscriptℝ𝑑\forall\bm{x}_{1},\ldots,\bm{x}_{m}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.

  3. (3)

    There exist constants M2,ζ^subscript𝑀2^𝜁M_{2},\widehat{\zeta} such that 1m​∑i∈V‖∇Fi​(𝒙)‖2≤ζ^2+M2​‖∇F​(𝒙)‖2,∀𝒙∈ℝdformulae-sequence1𝑚subscript𝑖𝑉superscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝒙2superscript^𝜁2subscript𝑀2superscriptnorm∇𝐹𝒙2for-all𝒙superscriptℝ𝑑{1\over m}\sum_{i\in V}\|\nabla F_{i}(\bm{x})\|^{2}\leq\widehat{\zeta}^{2}+M_{2}\|\nabla F(\bm{x})\|^{2},\forall\bm{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.

Let 𝑱:=1m​𝟏𝟏⊤assign𝑱1𝑚superscript11top\bm{J}:={1\over m}\bm{1}\bm{1}^{\top} denote an ideal m×m𝑚𝑚m\times m mixing matrix with all entries being 1m1𝑚{1\over m}.

Remark: While there exist other convergence bounds for D-PSGD such as (Wang et al., 2022b; Vogels et al., 2022; Neglia et al., 2020; Le Bars et al., 2023), we choose Theorem 3.4 as the theoretical foundation of our design due to the generality of its assumptions. For example, assumption (2) generalizes the assumption of uniformly bounded variance of stochastic gradients in (Wang et al., 2022b; Le Bars et al., 2023), assumption (3) generalizes the assumption of bounded data heterogeneity in (Wang et al., 2022b; Vogels et al., 2022; Neglia et al., 2020), and assumptions (2-3) are easily implied by the bounded gradient assumption in (Neglia et al., 2020) (see explanations in (Koloskova et al., 2020b)).

For tractability, we will focus on the case of i.i.d. mixing matrices. In this case, to achieve ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0\epsilon_{0}-convergence, it suffices for the number of iterations to reach K​(p,t)𝐾𝑝𝑡K(p,t) as in (15) for t=1𝑡1t=1. We note that K​(p,1)𝐾𝑝1K(p,1) depends on the mixing matrix only through the parameter p𝑝p: the larger p𝑝p, the smaller K​(p,1)𝐾𝑝1K(p,1). Recall that as explained in Section 2.3, the mixing matrix 𝑾𝑾\bm{W} is related to the link weights 𝜶𝜶\bm{\alpha} as 𝑾=𝑰−𝑩​diag⁡(𝜶)​𝑩⊤𝑾𝑰𝑩diag𝜶superscript𝑩top\bm{W}=\bm{I}-\bm{B}\operatorname{diag}(\bm{\alpha})\bm{B}^{\top}. To restrict the activated links to Easubscript𝐸𝑎E_{a}, we set αi​j=0subscript𝛼𝑖𝑗0\alpha_{ij}=0 for all (i,j)∉Ea𝑖𝑗subscript𝐸𝑎(i,j)\not\in E_{a}. Below, we will show that the following optimization gives a good design of the link weights:

(16a) min𝜶⁡ρsubscript𝜶𝜌\displaystyle\min_{\bm{\alpha}}\>\rho
(16b) s.t. −ρ​𝑰⪯𝑰−𝑩​diag⁡(𝜶)​𝑩⊤−𝑱⪯ρ​𝑰,precedes-or-equals𝜌𝑰𝑰𝑩diag𝜶superscript𝑩top𝑱precedes-or-equals𝜌𝑰\displaystyle-\rho\bm{I}\preceq\bm{I}-\bm{B}\operatorname{diag}(\bm{\alpha})\bm{B}^{\top}-\bm{J}\preceq\rho\bm{I},
(16c) αi​j=0,∀(i,j)∉Ea.formulae-sequencesubscript𝛼𝑖𝑗0for-all𝑖𝑗subscript𝐸𝑎\displaystyle\alpha_{ij}=0,~{}~{}\forall(i,j)\not\in E_{a}.
Corollary 3.5.

Under assumptions (1)–(3) and i.i.d. mixing matrices 𝑾(k)=d𝑾superscript𝑑superscript𝑾𝑘𝑾\bm{W}^{(k)}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle d}}{{=}}\bm{W} that is symmetric with each row/column summing to one, D-PSGD achieves ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0\epsilon_{0}-convergence as in Theorem 3.4 when the number of iterations reaches

(17) K​(1−IE​[‖𝑾−𝑱‖2],1).𝐾1IEdelimited-[]superscriptnorm𝑾𝑱21\displaystyle K(1-{\rm I\kern-3.00003ptE}[\|\bm{W}-\bm{J}\|^{2}],1).

Moreover, conditioned on the set of activated links being Easubscript𝐸𝑎E_{a}, (17) ≥K​(1−ρ∗2,1)absent𝐾1superscriptsuperscript𝜌21\geq K(1-\mathop{\rho^{*}}^{2},1), where ρ∗superscript𝜌\mathop{\rho^{*}} is the optimal value of (16), with “==” achieved at 𝑾∗=𝑰−𝑩​diag⁡(𝜶∗)​𝑩⊤superscript𝑾𝑰𝑩diagsuperscript𝜶superscript𝑩top\bm{W}^{*}=\bm{I}-\bm{B}\operatorname{diag}(\bm{\alpha}^{*})\bm{B}^{\top} for 𝜶∗superscript𝜶\bm{\alpha}^{*} being the optimal solution to (16).

Corollary 3.5 implies that given the set of activated links, we can design the corresponding link weights by solving (16), which will minimize an upper bound (17) on the number of iterations to achieve ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0\epsilon_{0}-convergence. Optimization (16) is a semi-definite programming (SDP) problem that can be solved in polynomial time by existing algorithms (Jiang et al., 2020).

Remark: When 𝑾𝑾\bm{W} satisfies the additional property of 𝑰⪰𝑾⪰−𝑰succeeds-or-equals𝑰𝑾succeeds-or-equals𝑰\bm{I}\succeq\bm{W}\succeq-\bm{I}, the largest singular value of 𝑾𝑾\bm{W} is 111 (Hua et al., 2022), and thus ‖𝑾−𝑱‖norm𝑾𝑱\|\bm{W}-\bm{J}\| is the second largest singular value of 𝑾𝑾\bm{W}. In this case, minimizing ρ𝜌\rho in (16) (which equals ‖𝑾−𝑱‖norm𝑾𝑱\|\bm{W}-\bm{J}\| under the optimal solution) is equivalent to maximizing γ​(𝑾):=1−‖𝑾−𝑱‖assign𝛾𝑾1norm𝑾𝑱\gamma(\bm{W}):=1-\|\bm{W}-\bm{J}\|, which is the spectral gap of the mixing matrix 𝑾𝑾\bm{W} (Neglia et al., 2020). The spectral gap is the most widely-used parameter to capture the impact of the mixing matrix on the convergence rate (Lian et al., 2017; Nedić et al., 2018; Neglia et al., 2019, 2020; Jiang et al., 2023). In this sense, our Corollary 3.5 extends the relationship between the spectral gap and the number of iterations to the case of random mixing matrices. As γ​(𝑾)→0→𝛾𝑾0\gamma(\bm{W})\to 0 (in probability), the number of iterations according to (17) grows at

(18) K​(1−IE​[(1−γ​(𝑾))2],1)𝐾1IEdelimited-[]superscript1𝛾𝑾21\displaystyle K\left(1-{\rm I\kern-3.00003ptE}[(1-\gamma(\bm{W}))^{2}],1\right) =O​(1IE​[γ​(𝑾)]),absent𝑂1IEdelimited-[]𝛾𝑾\displaystyle=O\left({1\over{\rm I\kern-3.00003ptE}[\gamma(\bm{W})]}\right),

which is consistent with the existing result of O​(1/γ​(𝑾))𝑂1𝛾𝑾O(1/\gamma(\bm{W})) in the case of deterministic mixing matrix (Neglia et al., 2020). While other parameters affecting the convergence rate have been identified, e.g., the effective number of neighbors (Vogels et al., 2022) and the neighborhood heterogeneity (Le Bars et al., 2023), these parameters are just additional factors instead of replacements of the spectral gap. We thus leave the optimization of these other objectives to future work.

3.3. Link Activation Optimization

Given how to optimize the communication schedule and the link weights for a given set Easubscript𝐸𝑎E_{a} of activated links as in Sections 3.1–3.2, what remains is to optimize Easubscript𝐸𝑎E_{a} itself, which is also known as “topology design” (Marfoq et al., 2020) as (V,Ea)𝑉subscript𝐸𝑎(V,E_{a}) depicts a subgraph of the base topology (of the overlay) that is used to determine which agents will exchange parameter vectors during DFL. The set Easubscript𝐸𝑎E_{a} affects both the communication demands (and hence the time per iteration) and the sparsity pattern of the mixing matrix (and hence the number of iterations required). As mentioned in Section 2.4, our goal is to minimize the total training time. For learning over bandwidth-limited networks, the training time is dominated by the communication time (Luo et al., 2020). We thus model the total training time by

(19) τ​(Ea)⋅K​(Ea),⋅𝜏subscript𝐸𝑎𝐾subscript𝐸𝑎\displaystyle\tau(E_{a})\cdot K(E_{a}),

where we have used τ​(Ea)𝜏subscript𝐸𝑎\tau(E_{a}) to denote the communication time per iteration according to (5) (with (5c) replaced by (12)), and K​(Ea):=K​(1−ρ∗2,1)assign𝐾subscript𝐸𝑎𝐾1superscriptsuperscript𝜌21K(E_{a}):=K(1-\mathop{\rho^{*}}^{2},1) to denote the number of iterations to achieve a given level of convergence. Our goal is to minimize (19) over all the candidate values of Ea⊆E~subscript𝐸𝑎~𝐸E_{a}\subseteq\widetilde{E}.

Directly solving this optimization is intractable because its solution space is exponentially large and its objective function (19) is not given explicitly. Our approach to address this challenge is to: (i) relax τ​(Ea)𝜏subscript𝐸𝑎\tau(E_{a}) and K​(Ea)𝐾subscript𝐸𝑎K(E_{a}) into upper bounds that are explicit functions of Easubscript𝐸𝑎E_{a}, (ii) decompose the optimization to separate the impacts of τ​(Ea)𝜏subscript𝐸𝑎\tau(E_{a}) and K​(Ea)𝐾subscript𝐸𝑎K(E_{a}), and (iii) develop efficient solutions by identifying linkages to known problems.

3.3.1. Relaxed Objective Function

We first upper-bound τ​(Ea)𝜏subscript𝐸𝑎\tau(E_{a}) by considering a suboptimal but analyzable communication schedule. Consider a solution to (5) with zi​jh=1subscriptsuperscript𝑧ℎ𝑖𝑗1z^{h}_{ij}=1 if i=sh,j∈Thformulae-sequence𝑖subscript𝑠ℎ𝑗subscript𝑇ℎi=s_{h},j\in T_{h} and 00 otherwise, and ri​jh,k=1subscriptsuperscript𝑟ℎ𝑘𝑖𝑗1r^{h,k}_{ij}=1 if i=sh,j=kformulae-sequence𝑖subscript𝑠ℎ𝑗𝑘i=s_{h},j=k and 00 otherwise, i.e., each parameter exchange corresponding to (i,j)∈Ea𝑖𝑗subscript𝐸𝑎(i,j)\in E_{a} is performed directly along the underlay routing paths p¯i,jsubscript¯𝑝𝑖𝑗\underline{p}_{i,j} and p¯j,isubscript¯𝑝𝑗𝑖\underline{p}_{j,i}. To achieve a per-iteration communication time of τ¯¯𝜏\overline{\tau}, the rate di,jsubscript𝑑𝑖𝑗d_{i,j} of sending the parameter vector of agent i𝑖i to its activated neighbor j𝑗j must satisfy di,j≥κiτ¯−li,j.subscript𝑑𝑖𝑗subscript𝜅𝑖¯𝜏subscript𝑙𝑖𝑗d_{i,j}\geq{\kappa_{i}\over\overline{\tau}-l_{i,j}}. This is feasible for (5) (with (5c) replaced by (12)) if and only if

(20) ∑(i,j)∈Ea(κiτ¯−li,j​𝟙(i,j)∈F+κjτ¯−lj,i​𝟙(j,i)∈F)≤C^F,∀F∈ℱ^.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑖𝑗subscript𝐸𝑎subscript𝜅𝑖¯𝜏subscript𝑙𝑖𝑗subscript1𝑖𝑗𝐹subscript𝜅𝑗¯𝜏subscript𝑙𝑗𝑖subscript1𝑗𝑖𝐹subscript^𝐶𝐹for-all𝐹^ℱ\displaystyle\sum_{(i,j)\in E_{a}}\left({\kappa_{i}\over\overline{\tau}-l_{i,j}}\mathbbm{1}_{(i,j)\in F}+{\kappa_{j}\over\overline{\tau}-l_{j,i}}\mathbbm{1}_{(j,i)\in F}\right)\leq\widehat{C}_{F},~{}~{}\forall F\in\widehat{\mathcal{F}}.

The minimum value of τ¯¯𝜏\overline{\tau} satisfying (20), denoted by τ¯​(Ea)¯𝜏subscript𝐸𝑎\overline{\tau}(E_{a}), thus provides an upper bound on the minimum per-iteration time τ​(Ea)𝜏subscript𝐸𝑎\tau(E_{a}) under the set of activated links in Easubscript𝐸𝑎E_{a}.

We then upper-bound K​(Ea)𝐾subscript𝐸𝑎K(E_{a}) by upper-bounding the optimal value ρ∗superscript𝜌\rho^{*} of (16). Consider any predetermined link weight assignment 𝜶(0)superscript𝜶0\bm{\alpha}^{(0)}, and let 𝜶(0)​(Ea)superscript𝜶0subscript𝐸𝑎\bm{\alpha}^{(0)}(E_{a}) be the corresponding feasible solution to (16) (i.e., (α(0)​(Ea))i​j=αi​j(0)subscriptsuperscript𝛼0subscript𝐸𝑎𝑖𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝛼0𝑖𝑗(\alpha^{(0)}(E_{a}))_{ij}=\alpha^{(0)}_{ij} if (i,j)∈Ea𝑖𝑗subscript𝐸𝑎(i,j)\in E_{a} and 00 otherwise). Let 𝑳​(Ea):=𝑩​diag⁡(𝜶(0)​(Ea))​𝑩⊤assign𝑳subscript𝐸𝑎𝑩diagsuperscript𝜶0subscript𝐸𝑎superscript𝑩top\bm{L}(E_{a}):=\bm{B}\operatorname{diag}(\bm{\alpha}^{(0)}(E_{a}))\bm{B}^{\top} denote the Laplacian matrix for the activated graph. Under this solution, the objective value of (16) is

(21) ρ¯¯𝜌\displaystyle\overline{\rho} :=‖𝑰−𝑳​(Ea)−𝑱‖assignabsentnorm𝑰𝑳subscript𝐸𝑎𝑱\displaystyle:=\|\bm{I}-\bm{L}(E_{a})-\bm{J}\|
(22) =max⁡(1−λ2​(𝑳​(Ea)),λm​(𝑳​(Ea))−1),absent1subscript𝜆2𝑳subscript𝐸𝑎subscript𝜆𝑚𝑳subscript𝐸𝑎1\displaystyle=\max(1-\lambda_{2}(\bm{L}(E_{a})),\>\lambda_{m}(\bm{L}(E_{a}))-1),

where (21) is from the proof of Corollary 3.5, and (22) is by (Chiu et al., 2023, Lemma IV.2) (where λi​(𝑳​(Ea))subscript𝜆𝑖𝑳subscript𝐸𝑎\lambda_{i}(\bm{L}(E_{a})) denotes the i𝑖i-th smallest eigenvalue of 𝑳​(Ea)𝑳subscript𝐸𝑎\bm{L}(E_{a})). Since K​(1−𝜌2,1)𝐾1superscript𝜌21K(1-\mathop{\rho}^{2},1) is an increasing function of ρ𝜌\rho and ρ∗≤ρ¯superscript𝜌¯𝜌\rho^{*}\leq\overline{\rho}, we have

(23) K(Ea):=K(1−ρ∗2,1)≤K(1−ρ¯2,1)=:K¯(Ea).\displaystyle K(E_{a}):=K\left(1-{\rho^{*}}^{2},1\right)\leq K\left(1-\overline{\rho}^{2},1\right)=:\overline{K}(E_{a}).

3.3.2. Bi-level Decomposition

Relaxing (19) into its upper bound τ¯​(Ea)⋅K¯​(Ea)⋅¯𝜏subscript𝐸𝑎¯𝐾subscript𝐸𝑎\overline{\tau}(E_{a})\cdot\overline{K}(E_{a}) provides an objective function that can be easily evaluated for any candidate Easubscript𝐸𝑎E_{a}. However, we still face the exponentially large solution space of Ea⊆E~subscript𝐸𝑎~𝐸E_{a}\subseteq\widetilde{E}. To address this complexity challenge, we decompose the relaxed optimization into a bi-level optimization as follows.

Lemma 3.6.

Let β𝛽\beta be the maximum time per iteration. Then

(24) minEa⊆E~⁡τ¯​(Ea)⋅K¯​(Ea)=minβ≥0⁡β⋅(minτ¯​(Ea)≤β⁡K¯​(Ea)),⋅subscriptsubscript𝐸𝑎~𝐸¯𝜏subscript𝐸𝑎¯𝐾subscript𝐸𝑎⋅subscript𝛽0𝛽subscript¯𝜏subscript𝐸𝑎𝛽¯𝐾subscript𝐸𝑎\displaystyle\min_{E_{a}\subseteq\widetilde{E}}\overline{\tau}(E_{a})\cdot\overline{K}(E_{a})=\min_{\beta\geq 0}\beta\cdot\left(\min_{\overline{\tau}(E_{a})\leq\beta}\overline{K}(E_{a})\right),

and the optimal solution Ea∗superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑎E_{a}^{*} to the RHS of (24) is also optimal for the LHS of (24).

The bi-level decomposition in (24) allows us to focus on the lower-level optimization

(25) minτ¯​(Ea)≤β⁡K¯​(Ea),subscript¯𝜏subscript𝐸𝑎𝛽¯𝐾subscript𝐸𝑎\displaystyle\min_{\overline{\tau}(E_{a})\leq\beta}\overline{K}(E_{a}),

as the upper-level optimization only has a scalar variable β𝛽\beta that can be optimized numerically once we have an efficient solution to (25).

3.3.3. Algorithms

To solve (25), we encode Easubscript𝐸𝑎E_{a} by binary variables 𝒚:=(yi​j)(i,j)∈E~assign𝒚subscriptsubscript𝑦𝑖𝑗𝑖𝑗~𝐸\bm{y}:=(y_{ij})_{(i,j)\in\widetilde{E}}, where yi​j=1subscript𝑦𝑖𝑗1y_{ij}=1 if (i,j)∈Ea𝑖𝑗subscript𝐸𝑎(i,j)\in E_{a} and 00 otherwise. By (20), 𝒚𝒚\bm{y} is feasible for (25) if and only if ∀F∈ℱ^for-all𝐹^ℱ\forall F\in\widehat{\mathcal{F}},

(26) ∑(i,j)∈E~yi​j​(κiβ−li,j​𝟙(i,j)∈F+κjβ−lj,i​𝟙(j,i)∈F)≤C^F,subscript𝑖𝑗~𝐸subscript𝑦𝑖𝑗subscript𝜅𝑖𝛽subscript𝑙𝑖𝑗subscript1𝑖𝑗𝐹subscript𝜅𝑗𝛽subscript𝑙𝑗𝑖subscript1𝑗𝑖𝐹subscript^𝐶𝐹\displaystyle\sum_{(i,j)\in\widetilde{E}}y_{ij}\left({\kappa_{i}\over\beta-l_{i,j}}\mathbbm{1}_{(i,j)\in F}+{\kappa_{j}\over\beta-l_{j,i}}\mathbbm{1}_{(j,i)\in F}\right)\leq\widehat{C}_{F},

where 𝟙⋅subscript1⋅\mathbbm{1}_{\cdot} denotes the indicator function.

Exact solution: We can directly try to solve the lower-level optimization (25) as a convex programming problem with integer variables. Due to the monotone relationship between K¯​(Ea)¯𝐾subscript𝐸𝑎\overline{K}(E_{a}) and ρ¯¯𝜌\overline{\rho}, we can equivalently minimize ρ¯¯𝜌\overline{\rho} as defined in (21) by solving

(27a) min𝒚subscript𝒚\displaystyle\min_{\bm{y}} ρ𝜌\displaystyle\quad\rho
(27b) s.t. −ρ​𝑰⪯𝑰−∑(i,j)∈E~yi​j​𝑳i​j−𝑱⪯ρ​𝑰,precedes-or-equals𝜌𝑰𝑰subscript𝑖𝑗~𝐸subscript𝑦𝑖𝑗subscript𝑳𝑖𝑗𝑱precedes-or-equals𝜌𝑰\displaystyle-\rho\bm{I}\preceq\bm{I}-\sum_{(i,j)\in\widetilde{E}}y_{ij}\bm{L}_{ij}-\bm{J}\preceq\rho\bm{I},
(27c) (​26​),∀F∈ℱ^,italic-(26italic-)for-all𝐹^ℱ\displaystyle\eqref{eq:independence constraint},~{}~{}\forall F\in\widehat{\mathcal{F}},
(27d) yi​j∈{0,1},∀(i,j)∈E~,formulae-sequencesubscript𝑦𝑖𝑗01for-all𝑖𝑗~𝐸\displaystyle y_{ij}\in\{0,1\},~{}~{}\forall(i,j)\in\widetilde{E},

where 𝑳i​jsubscript𝑳𝑖𝑗\bm{L}_{ij} is the Laplacian matrix representation of link (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j) with weight αi​j(0)subscriptsuperscript𝛼0𝑖𝑗\alpha^{(0)}_{ij}, i.e., entries (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j) and (j,i)𝑗𝑖(j,i) are −αi​j(0)subscriptsuperscript𝛼0𝑖𝑗-\alpha^{(0)}_{ij} and entries (i,i)𝑖𝑖(i,i) and (j,j)𝑗𝑗(j,j) are αi​j(0)subscriptsuperscript𝛼0𝑖𝑗\alpha^{(0)}_{ij} (rest are zero), and (27b) ensures that the auxiliary variable ρ=ρ¯𝜌¯𝜌\rho=\overline{\rho} as in (21) under the optimal solution.

The optimization (27) is an integer convex programming (ICP) problem, and thus in theory can be solved by ICP solvers such as (Lubin, 2017). In practice, however, ICP solvers can be slow due to their super-polynomial complexity, and in contrast to the communication schedule optimization (5) that only needs to be solved once, (27) has to be solved many times to optimize the variable β𝛽\beta in the upper-level optimization. Thus, we need more efficient algorithms.

Efficient heuristics: To improve the computational efficiency, we have explored two approaches: (i) developing heuristics for (27), and (ii) further simplifying the objective function.

∙∙\bullet Heuristics for (27): Once we relax the integer constraint (27d) into yi​j∈[0,1]subscript𝑦𝑖𝑗01y_{ij}\in[0,1], (27) becomes an SDP that can be solved in polynomial time (Jiang et al., 2020). We can thus round the fractional solution into a feasible solution. However, we observe that simple rounding schemes such as greedily activating links with the largest fractional y𝑦y-values do not yield a good solution (see results for ‘Relaxation-ρ𝜌\rho’ in Section 4). Thus, we propose an iterative rounding algorithm based on successive convex approximation (SCA) as in Algorithm 1. The algorithm gradually rounds the y𝑦y-values for a subset of links Essubscript𝐸𝑠E_{s} to 111 and those for another subset of links Eosubscript𝐸𝑜E_{o} to 00 to satisfy feasibility. In each iteration, it solves the SDP relaxation of (27) with rounding constraints according to the previously computed Essubscript𝐸𝑠E_{s} and Eosubscript𝐸𝑜E_{o} (line 1), and then adds the link with the largest fractional y𝑦y-value to Essubscript𝐸𝑠E_{s} (lines 1–1) and the link with the smallest fractional y𝑦y-value to Eosubscript𝐸𝑜E_{o} (lines 1–1). The iteration repeats until the integer solution rounded according to a given threshold ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is feasible for (27) (line 1).

∙∙\bullet Heuristics based on algebraic connectivity: Another approach is to simplify the objective based on the following observation.

Lemma 3.7.

Minimizing ρ¯¯𝜌\overline{\rho} in (22) is equivalent to maximizing λ2​(𝑳​(Ea))subscript𝜆2𝑳subscript𝐸𝑎\lambda_{2}(\bm{L}(E_{a})) (the second smallest eigenvalue) if 𝜶(0)superscript𝜶0\bm{\alpha}^{(0)} satisfies

(28) maxi∈V​∑j:(i,j)∈E~αi​j(0)+m⋅max(i,j)∈E~⁡|αi​j(0)|≤1.subscript𝑖𝑉subscript:𝑗𝑖𝑗~𝐸subscriptsuperscript𝛼0𝑖𝑗⋅𝑚subscript𝑖𝑗~𝐸subscriptsuperscript𝛼0𝑖𝑗1\displaystyle\max_{i\in V}\sum_{j:(i,j)\in\widetilde{E}}\alpha^{(0)}_{ij}+m\cdot\max_{(i,j)\in\widetilde{E}}|\alpha^{(0)}_{ij}|\leq 1.

Remark: We can satisfy (28) by making αi​j(0)subscriptsuperscript𝛼0𝑖𝑗\alpha^{(0)}_{ij}’s sufficiently small, e.g., αi​j(0)≡1/(2​m−1)subscriptsuperscript𝛼0𝑖𝑗12𝑚1\alpha^{(0)}_{ij}\equiv 1/(2m-1), ∀(i,j)∈E~for-all𝑖𝑗~𝐸\forall(i,j)\in\widetilde{E}.

Under condition (28), we can convert the minimization of ρ¯¯𝜌\overline{\rho} into a maximization of λ2​(𝑳​(Ea))subscript𝜆2𝑳subscript𝐸𝑎\lambda_{2}(\bm{L}(E_{a})), known as the algebraic connectivity:

(29a) max𝒚subscript𝒚\displaystyle\max_{\bm{y}} λ2​(∑(i,j)∈E~yi​j​𝑳i​j)subscript𝜆2subscript𝑖𝑗~𝐸subscript𝑦𝑖𝑗subscript𝑳𝑖𝑗\displaystyle\quad\lambda_{2}(\sum_{(i,j)\in\widetilde{E}}y_{ij}\bm{L}_{ij})
(29b) s.t. (​26​),∀F∈ℱ^,italic-(26italic-)for-all𝐹^ℱ\displaystyle\eqref{eq:independence constraint},~{}~{}\forall F\in\widehat{\mathcal{F}},
(29c) yi​j∈{0,1},∀(i,j)∈E~,formulae-sequencesubscript𝑦𝑖𝑗01for-all𝑖𝑗~𝐸\displaystyle y_{ij}\in\{0,1\},~{}~{}\forall(i,j)\in\widetilde{E},

which selects links to maximize the algebraic connectivity under the linear constraints (29b). A similar problem of maximizing the algebraic connectivity of unweighted graphs under cardinality constraint (i.e., ∑(i,j)∈E~yi​j≤ksubscript𝑖𝑗~𝐸subscript𝑦𝑖𝑗𝑘\sum_{(i,j)\in\widetilde{E}}y_{ij}\leq k) has been studied with some efficient heuristics (Ghosh and Boyd, 2006; He, 2019). Although our problem (29) addresses a weighted graph and more general linear constraints, the existing heuristics can still be adapted for our problem.

Specifically, as λ2​(∑(i,j)∈E~yi​j​𝑳i​j)subscript𝜆2subscript𝑖𝑗~𝐸subscript𝑦𝑖𝑗subscript𝑳𝑖𝑗\lambda_{2}(\sum_{(i,j)\in\widetilde{E}}y_{ij}\bm{L}_{ij}) is a concave function of 𝒚𝒚\bm{y} (Ghosh and Boyd, 2006), relaxing the integer constraint (29c) into yi​j∈[0,1]subscript𝑦𝑖𝑗01y_{ij}\in[0,1] turns (29) into a convex optimization that can be solved in polynomial time, based on which we can extract an integer solution via rounding. We can also adapt the greedy perturbation heuristic in (Ghosh and Boyd, 2006) as follows. Let 𝒗​(Ea)𝒗subscript𝐸𝑎\bm{v}(E_{a}) denote the Fiedler vector of 𝑳​(Ea)𝑳subscript𝐸𝑎\bm{L}(E_{a}) (i.e., the unit-norm eigenvector corresponding to λ2​(𝑳​(Ea))subscript𝜆2𝑳subscript𝐸𝑎\lambda_{2}(\bm{L}(E_{a}))). It is easy to extend (Ghosh and Boyd, 2006, (10)) into

(30) λ2​(𝑳​(Ea∪{(i,j)}))−λ2​(𝑳​(Ea))≤αi​j(0)​(v​(Ea)i−v​(Ea)j)2.subscript𝜆2𝑳subscript𝐸𝑎𝑖𝑗subscript𝜆2𝑳subscript𝐸𝑎subscriptsuperscript𝛼0𝑖𝑗superscript𝑣subscriptsubscript𝐸𝑎𝑖𝑣subscriptsubscript𝐸𝑎𝑗2\displaystyle\lambda_{2}(\bm{L}(E_{a}\cup\{(i,j)\}))-\lambda_{2}(\bm{L}(E_{a}))\leq\alpha^{(0)}_{ij}\left(v(E_{a})_{i}-v(E_{a})_{j}\right)^{2}.

Based on this bound, we can apply the greedy heuristic to (29) by repeatedly: (i) computing the Fiedler vector 𝒗​(Ea)𝒗subscript𝐸𝑎\bm{v}(E_{a}) based on the current Easubscript𝐸𝑎E_{a}, and (ii) augmenting Easubscript𝐸𝑎E_{a} with the link (i,j)∈E~∖Ea𝑖𝑗~𝐸subscript𝐸𝑎(i,j)\in\widetilde{E}\setminus E_{a} that maximizes αi​j(0)​(v​(Ea)i−v​(Ea)j)2subscriptsuperscript𝛼0𝑖𝑗superscript𝑣subscriptsubscript𝐸𝑎𝑖𝑣subscriptsubscript𝐸𝑎𝑗2\alpha^{(0)}_{ij}\left(v(E_{a})_{i}-v(E_{a})_{j}\right)^{2} subject to (26).

Remark: Even if we can enforce the condition in Lemma 3.7 by suitably setting the initial link weights 𝜶(0)superscript𝜶0\bm{\alpha}^{(0)}, the final link weights are determined by the optimization (16) and thus cannot guarantee the equivalence between ρ¯¯𝜌\overline{\rho} minimization and algebraic connectivity maximization. As a result, our evaluation shows that Easubscript𝐸𝑎E_{a}’s designed by the above heuristics based on the algebraic connectivity are less effective than those designed based on ρ¯¯𝜌\overline{\rho} (see Section 4). However, connecting our problem with algebraic connectivity maximization opens the possibility of leveraging a rich set of existing results, for which the above is just a starting point. In this regard, our contribution is to formally establish this connection and the corresponding condition.

3.4. Overall Solution

Fig. 4 illustrates the overall proposed solution as deployed on a centralized orchestrator when initializing DFL tasks, which starts by inferring the necessary information about the underlay using network tomography (Huang and He, 2023), and then selects the links to activate based on predetermined weights 𝜶(0)superscript𝜶0\bm{\alpha}^{(0)} as in Section 3.3, based on which the link weights are optimized as in Section 3.2 and the communication schedule is optimized as in Section 3.1. Our solution is suitable for the centralized deployment as it only uses predetermined information.

The performance of this solution is guaranteed as follows.

Theorem 3.8.

Under the assumption of ℱ^⊇ℱℱ^ℱ\widehat{\mathcal{F}}\supseteq\mathcal{F} and C^F≤CFsubscript^𝐶𝐹subscript𝐶𝐹\widehat{C}_{F}\leq C_{F} (∀F∈ℱfor-all𝐹ℱ\forall F\in\mathcal{F}), if the proposed solution activates a set of links Ea∗superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑎E_{a}^{*}, then D-PSGD under the corresponding design is guaranteed to achieve ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0\epsilon_{0}-convergence as defined in Theorem 3.4 within time τ¯​(Ea∗)⋅K¯​(Ea∗)⋅¯𝜏superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑎¯𝐾superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑎\overline{\tau}(E_{a}^{*})\cdot\overline{K}(E_{a}^{*}) for τ¯​(⋅)¯𝜏⋅\overline{\tau}(\cdot) and K¯​(⋅)¯𝐾⋅\overline{K}(\cdot) defined in Section 3.3.1.

Remark: Theorem 3.8 upper-bounds the total training time under our design if network tomography detects all the nonempty categories and does not overestimate the category capacities. According to (Huang and He, 2023), the second assumption holds approximately as the estimation of category capacities is highly accurate, but the first assumption may not hold due to misses in detecting nonempty categories. However, in underlays following symmetric tree-based routing as commonly encountered in edge networks, a new algorithm in (Huang and He, 2024) can detect nearly all the nonempty categories in networks of moderate sizes. We will empirically evaluate the impact of inference errors on the final performance of DFL in Section 4.

4. Performance Evaluation

We evaluate the proposed algorithms against benchmarks through realistic data-driven simulations in the context of bandwidth-limited wireless edge networks.

4.1. Simulation Setup

4.1.1. Dataset and ML Model

We train a ResNet-50 model with 23,616,394 parameters and a model size of 90.09 MB for image classification on the CIFAR-10 dataset, which consists of 60,000 color images divided into 10 classes. We use 50,000 images for training and the remaining 10,000 images for testing. The dataset undergoes standard preprocessing, including normalization and one-hot encoding of the labels. We set the learning rate to 0.020.020.02 and the mini-batch size to 64 for each agent. These settings are sufficient for D-PSGD to achieve convergence under all evaluated designs. As a sanity check, we also train a 4-layer CNN model based on (McMahan et al., 2017), which has 582,026 parameters and a model size of 2.22 MB, for digit recognition on the MNIST dataset, which comprises 60,000 training images and 10,000 testing images. In both cases, we evenly divide the training data among all the agents after a random shuffle.

4.1.2. Network Topology

We simulate the underlay based on the topologies and link attributes of real wireless edge networks. We consider two important types of networks: (i) WiFi-based wireless mesh networks represented by the Roofnet (Aguayo et al., 2004), which has 33 nodes, 187 links, and a data rate of 1 Mbps, and (ii) millimeter-wave-based Integrated Access and Backhaul (IAB) networks used to extend the coverage of 5G networks (3GPP, 2018), represented by a hexagon topology with 19 nodes, 56 links, and a data rate of 0.40.40.4 Gbps (Ronkainen et al., 2020). In each topology, we select 101010 low-degree nodes as learning agents (i.e., overlay nodes). We assume the base topology to be a clique among the agents (i.e., any two agents are allowed to communicate), and use the shortest paths (based on hop count) between the agents as the underlay routing paths. The simulated topologies are illustrated in Fig. 5.

4.1.3. Benchmarks

We compare the proposed Algorithm 1 (‘SCA’) against the following benchmarks:

  • •

    the baseline of activating all the (overlay) links (‘Clique’);

  • •

    the ring topology (‘Ring’) commonly adopted by industry;

  • •

    the minimum spanning tree computed by Prim’s algorithm (‘Prim’), proposed by (Marfoq et al., 2020) as the state of the art for overlay-based DFL;

  • •

    the simplistic heuristic for (27) based on SDP relaxation plus greedy rounding (‘Relaxation-ρ𝜌\rho’);

  • •

    the heuristics for (29) based on convex relaxation plus rounding (‘Relaxation-λ𝜆\lambda’) or greedy perturbation (Ghosh and Boyd, 2006) (‘Greedy’).

We will first evaluate a basic setting where we provide accurate information about the underlay to all the algorithms, use (16) to optimize the link weights under each topology design, and let all the communications occur directly over the underlay routing paths (i.e., without overlay routing). We will separately evaluate the impact of overlay routing, inference errors, and weight design.

4.2. Simulation Results on Roofnet

4.2.1. Results without Overlay Routing

As the most difficult part of our problem is topology design (i.e., optimization of Easubscript𝐸𝑎E_{a}), we first compare the topology design solutions without overlay routing. As shown in Fig. 6, (i) using sparse topologies rather than the clique can effectively reduce the training time without compromising the performance at convergence, (ii) different topology designs only slightly differ in terms of the convergence rate over epochs, but can differ significantly in terms of the convergence rate over the actual (wall-clock) time, and (iii) the proposed design by ‘SCA’ notably outperforms the others in terms of training time, while achieving the same loss/accuracy at convergence. Note that the time axis is in log scale. A closer examination further shows that the existing topology designs (‘Prim’, ‘Ring’) work relatively well in that they not only converge much faster than the baseline (‘Clique’) but also outperform the other heuristics based on the optimizations we formulate (‘Relaxation-ρ𝜌\rho’, ‘Relaxation-λ𝜆\lambda’, ‘Greedy’). Nevertheless, ‘SCA’ is able to converge even faster by better approximating the optimal solution to (27). Note that although we have not optimized overlay routing, the proposed algorithm still benefits from the knowledge of how links are shared by routing paths within the underlay (via constraint (26)), which allows it to better balance the convergence rate and the communication time per iteration, while the state-of-the-art design (‘Prim’) ignores such link sharing. This result highlights the importance of underlay-aware design for overlay-based DFL.

Meanwhile, we note that the simpler heuristics ‘Relaxation-ρ𝜌\rho’ and ‘Relaxation-λ𝜆\lambda’ outperform ‘SCA’ in terms of running time, as shown in Table 1, and all the algorithms based on our optimizations are slower than ‘Prim’. This indicates further room for improvement for future work in terms of the tradeoff between the quality of design and the computational efficiency.

4.2.2. Results with Overlay Routing

Fig. 7 shows the results after optimizing the communication schedule under each design by the overlay routing optimization (5). Compared with Fig. 6 (second row), we see that the training time is further reduced for all the topology designs. However, the improvement is only prominent for the dense topology (‘Clique’) with a reduction of 28%percent2828\%, while the improvement for the other topologies is incremental (222–4%percent44\%). Intuitively, this is because these sparse topologies generate much less load on the underlay network, and hence leave less room for improvement for overlay routing.

4.2.3. Results with Inference Errors

While the above results are obtained under the perfect knowledge of the nonempty categories ℱℱ\mathcal{F} and the category capacities (CF)F∈ℱsubscriptsubscript𝐶𝐹𝐹ℱ(C_{F})_{F\in\mathcal{F}}, the observations therein remain valid under the inferred values of these parameters, as shown in Fig. 8, where the inference is performed by the T-COIN algorithm in (Huang and He, 2024) based on packet-level simulations in NS3. Compared with the results under perfect knowledge in Fig. 6–7, designing the communication demands and schedule based on the inferred information only slightly perturbs the training performance, and the comparison between different designs remains roughly the same.

4.2.4. Results under Other Weight Design

Instead of solving the SDP (16), one could use other designs of link weights. To see the impact of weight design, we have repeated the simulations in Fig. 6–7 under a common design called Metropolis-Hasting weights (Xiao et al., 2006). The results in Fig. 9 show that the Metropolis-Hasting weights introduce a noticeable delay in convergence compared to our proposed weight design, as evidenced by comparing each curve in Fig. 9 with its counterpart in Fig. 6–7.

4.2.5. Results on MNIST

To check the generalizability of our observations wrt the learning task, we repeat the above tests on MNIST based on the same network topology. The results in Fig. 10–11 show the following ranking of the algorithms: ‘SCA’ performs the best, ‘Clique’ performs the worst, and the rest (‘Prim’, ‘Ring’, ‘Relaxation-ρ𝜌\rho’, ‘Greedy’, and ‘Relaxation-λ𝜆\lambda’) fall in between. The inference errors may change the exact performance of each design, but their comparison remains largely the same. Compared with CIFAR-10, we see that although the small size of MNIST causes the gaps between algorithms to shrink, their comparison remains the same.

4.3. Simulation Results on IAB Network

To further validate our observations in different network scenarios, we repeat the previous tests on the IAB network, as shown in Fig. 12–15. The results exhibit similar trends as those on Roofnet (Fig. 6–11), in that the sparse topologies significantly reduce the time in achieving the same level of convergence as the clique, and overlay routing brings more improvement to dense topologies like the clique. Meanwhile, there is also a notable difference: except for the clique, all the topologies perform similarly on the IAB network. Further examination shows that this is because the IAB network is smaller, with fewer hops between the learning agents and less link sharing, and thus leaves less room for improvement. Nevertheless, the proposed algorithm ‘SCA’ is still among the best-performing solutions. This result demonstrates the generalizability of our previous observations.

4.4. Summary of Results

Tables 2–5 summarize the above results in terms of the total wall clock time for DFL to reach convergence, defined as the point at which the variance of accuracy within a sliding window falls below a specified threshold777Specifically, we consider convergence to be achieved when the variance of accuracy within a window of three consecutive epochs remains below 0.0050.0050.005 for at least three consecutive windows.. The results clearly show that (i) using a sparse topology for parameter exchange can significantly reduce the training time compared to using the complete topology, (ii) overlay routing can further improve the training time, although the improvement is much less, and (iii) the state-of-the-art network tomography algorithm (Huang and He, 2024) is accurate enough to support the optimization.

5. Conclusion

We considered, for the first time, communication optimization for running DFL on top of a bandwidth-limited underlay network. To this end, we formulated a framework for jointly optimizing the hyperparameters controlling the communication demands between learning agents and the communication schedule (including routing and flow rates) to fulfill such demands, without cooperation from the underlay. We showed that the resulting problem can be decomposed into a set of interrelated subproblems, and developed efficient algorithms through carefully designed convex relaxations. Our evaluations based on real topologies and datasets validated the efficacy of the proposed solution in significantly reducing the training time without compromising the quality of the trained model. Our results highlight the need of network-application co-design in supporting DFL over bandwidth-limited networks, and our overlay-based approach facilitates the deployment of our solution in existing networks without changing their internal operations.

A. Supporting Proofs

Proof of Lemma 3.1.

The rate of each multicast flow h∈Hℎ𝐻h\in H is determined by the minimum rate of the unicast flows constituting it. Consider the bottleneck underlay link e¯∗:=arg⁡mine¯∈E¯⁡Ce¯/te¯assignsuperscript¯𝑒subscript¯𝑒¯𝐸subscript𝐶¯𝑒subscript𝑡¯𝑒\underline{e}^{*}:=\operatorname{\arg\min}_{\underline{e}\in\underline{E}}C_{\underline{e}}/t_{\underline{e}}. Since there are te¯∗subscript𝑡superscript¯𝑒t_{\underline{e}^{*}} unicast flows sharing a total bandwidth of Ce¯∗subscript𝐶superscript¯𝑒C_{\underline{e}^{*}} at e¯∗superscript¯𝑒\underline{e}^{*}, the slowest of these flows cannot have a rate higher than Ce¯∗/te¯∗subscript𝐶superscript¯𝑒subscript𝑡superscript¯𝑒C_{\underline{e}^{*}}/t_{\underline{e}^{*}}. Thus, the multicast flow containing this slowest unicast flow cannot have a rate higher than Ce¯∗/te¯∗subscript𝐶superscript¯𝑒subscript𝑡superscript¯𝑒C_{\underline{e}^{*}}/t_{\underline{e}^{*}}, which means that the completion time for all the multicast flows is no smaller than (7).

Meanwhile, if the bandwidth of every link is shared equally among the activated unicast flows traversing it, then each unicast flow will receive a bandwidth allocation of no less than Ce¯∗/te¯∗subscript𝐶superscript¯𝑒subscript𝑡superscript¯𝑒C_{\underline{e}^{*}}/t_{\underline{e}^{*}} at every hop, and thus can achieve a rate of at least Ce¯∗/te¯∗subscript𝐶superscript¯𝑒subscript𝑡superscript¯𝑒C_{\underline{e}^{*}}/t_{\underline{e}^{*}}. Hence, each multicast flow h∈Hℎ𝐻h\in H can achieve a rate of at least Ce¯∗/te¯∗subscript𝐶superscript¯𝑒subscript𝑡superscript¯𝑒C_{\underline{e}^{*}}/t_{\underline{e}^{*}}, yielding a completion time of no more than (7). ∎

Proof of Lemma 3.3.

According to Lemma 3.1, it suffices to prove that minF∈ℱ⁡CF/tF=mine¯∈E¯⁡Ce¯/te¯subscript𝐹ℱsubscript𝐶𝐹subscript𝑡𝐹subscript¯𝑒¯𝐸subscript𝐶¯𝑒subscript𝑡¯𝑒\min_{F\in\mathcal{F}}C_{F}/t_{F}=\min_{\underline{e}\in\underline{E}}C_{\underline{e}}/t_{\underline{e}}. ∎

Proof of Lemma 3.7.

Proof of Theorem 3.8.

Under the assumption of ℱ^⊇ℱℱ^ℱ\widehat{\mathcal{F}}\supseteq\mathcal{F} and C^F≤CFsubscript^𝐶𝐹subscript𝐶𝐹\widehat{C}_{F}\leq C_{F} (∀F∈ℱfor-all𝐹ℱ\forall F\in\mathcal{F}), every real (per-category) capacity constraint is ensured by a capacity constraint we formulate based on the inferred parameters ℱ^^ℱ\widehat{\mathcal{F}} and (C^F)F∈ℱ^subscriptsubscript^𝐶𝐹𝐹^ℱ(\widehat{C}_{F})_{F\in\widehat{\mathcal{F}}}, and thus any communication schedule that is feasible under the inferred constraints remains feasible under the actual constraints. This implies that the proposed design predicted to complete each iteration in time τ¯​(Ea∗)¯𝜏superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑎\overline{\tau}(E_{a}^{*}) can actually complete each iteration within this time. Moreover, by Corollary 3.5, D-PSGD under the designed mixing matrix achieves ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0\epsilon_{0}-convergence within K​(Ea∗)𝐾superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑎K(E_{a}^{*}) iterations, which is further bounded by K¯​(Ea∗)¯𝐾superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑎\overline{K}(E_{a}^{*}) according to (23). Thus, D-PSGD under the proposed design can achieve ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0\epsilon_{0}-convergence within time τ¯​(Ea∗)⋅K¯​(Ea∗)⋅¯𝜏superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑎¯𝐾superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑎\overline{\tau}(E_{a}^{*})\cdot\overline{K}(E_{a}^{*}). ∎
